text: Good morning boys and girls.
speaker: teacher

text: Good morning Mr. [Inaudible].
speaker: multiple students

text: This morning we are going to continue with [inaudible] 7, moving between solids and silhouettes.  And we are going to be doing session 2.1, “Silhouettes of Geometric Solids.” Today you should be able to analyze the silhouettes of 3D solids and also be able to match solids and silhouettes. Last time we did, again, was the shape, and we were able to explore the attributes of three-dimensional solids.  We talked about [faces] being a point on the solid where two or more edges meet.  And when two faces meet together, we say that this is an edge.  And we also identified that the 3D solids are made up of 2D faces.  We noted that some of the faces were squares; some of their faces were triangles. So today we are going to continue by looking at the silhouettes.  Anybody here knows anything about silhouettes? Yes?
speaker: teacher

text: It’s like a shadow of the shape but you only see one side.
speaker: student

text: Thank you! It is exactly a shadow, the shadow of the shape. How many have known about this word before?  Oh good, good. So today we are going to learn something new, and then you can go home and share with your parents.  [Inaudible] Silhouettes are the black shadows or shapes produced when an object lost light.  Now when the sun’s rays are out there and you are walking, what do you see on the ground?
speaker: teacher

text: Your shadow.
speaker: student

text: Your shadow.  Have you ever asked yourself why you are seeing your shadow?   It looks kind of crooked, right? But it’s dark solid.  It is dark because your body is a solid mass. Light cannot penetrate through you.  So the light is reflected and your shadow is thrown on the ground.  The length of your shadow will depend on the time of the day. So likewise this morning we’re going to be looking at the images, the silhouettes that we produce when we put our three-dimensional solids on this projector so that you can be blocking the light from the – the mirror here will reflect the light coming from the projector so that the shadow or the silhouette of our shape will be projected on the screen. Watch what happens when I put my hand.  Do you see the outline of my hand?  But you cannot see my veins, you cannot see anything, you just see the shadow of my hand.  What is causing this is because the light from this cannot penetrate through my hand, so it bounces on this mirror and is reflected away, and that’s why it casts that shadow.  So that is what we call silhouettes.  Any question about silhouettes and what it means? So we’re going to be looking at shadows.  If you don’t remember the word silhouette, remember that a silhouette is a shadow produced when any solid object lost light.  The solid object cannot absorb the light so the light is reflected away from that surface, and then you see the black shadow. So, I’m going to pull out the first geometric solid, and then we’ll have to identify the name like we did last time.  What is the name of this solid?  Student J?
